questions.text: A 40-year-old male comes to the surgery out-patient clinic with the following appearance of his lower limb.  Which of the following forms a surface landmark for the structure shown?

choices.text: On the lateral border of the tibia at the junction of upper 2/3rd and lower 1/3rd
Just medial to the tendo-calcaneus above the medial malleolus
Dorsum of the foot, at the medial end of the dorsal venous arch
Dorsum of the foot, at the lateral end of the dorsal venous arch

questions.solution:
The image shows varicosities of the great saphenous vein. 

The surface marking for it is marked by joining the following points from foot to thigh

  1. On the dorsum of the foot, at the medial end of the dorsal venous arch
  2. On the anterior surface of medial malleolus 
  3. On the medial border of the tibia at the junction of the upper 2/3rd and lower 1/3rd of the leg
  4. At the adductor tubercle
  5. Just below the center of the saphenous opening 

The small saphenous vein is marked by-

  1. On the dorsum of the foot, at the lateral end of the dorsal venous arch
  2. Behind the lateral malleolus 
  3. Just lateral to the tendocalcaneous above the lateral malleolus 
  4. At the center of the popliteal fossa draining into the popliteal vein

questions.text: Which structure prevents the ascent of the horseshoe kidney?
questions.solution:
The inferior mesenteric artery (marked as C) prevents the ascent of the horseshoe kidney.

A- Femoral cutaneous nerve 

B- Right ureter

D- Left ureter

The inferior mesenteric artery branches off from the anterior surface of the abdominal aorta usually 3-4 cm above the aortic bifurcation at the L3 vertebral level.

Horseshoe kidney is caused due to the fusion of lower poles of the kidney and it's ascent is prevented by the inferior mesenteric artery. Hence they cannot reach the normal level of T12- L3 and found low lying, ususally in the lower abdomen. Horseshoe kidneys are prone to reflux, obstruction, and stone formation.

questions.text: During the abdominal examination, the consultant asks the patient to draw the legs up to relax the abdomen during palpation. What is the structure responsible for the relaxation of the abdominal wall?
questions.solution:
Tensor fascia lata is responsible for the relaxation of the abdominal wall when the patient flexes their hips.

Fascia lata is a tough, fibrous layer that wraps around the thigh like a sleeve. It is attached to the inguinal ligament. Extension of the thighs pulls the abdominal wall downwards and makes it tense. To relax the abdomen fully for palpation by an examining physician, the patient is asked to draw the legs up. This overcomes the pull of the fascia lata on the abdominal wall.

Attachment:

  • At the Top (Superiorly):
  • Front: To the inguinal ligament.
  • Side: To the iliac crest.
  • Back: To the sacrum and other nearby structures.
  • Inner Side: To the pubic bone and ischial tuberosity.
  • At the Bottom (Inferiorly):
  • Front and Sides of the Knee: Attaches to the knee joint and nearby bony areas.
  • Back of the Knee: Becomes the popliteal fascia and connects to the back of the leg.
  • It helps to hold the thigh muscles, divides the thigh into different sections and transfers the force from the muscles to the knee and hip. 

Modifications of fascia lata are iliotibial tract, saphenous opening and intermuscular septa.

questions.text: A patient who recently underwent parotidectomy presents with flushing, sweating, and a burning sensation on the left side of the face during a meal. Injury to postganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibers of which of the following nerves can result in this?
questions.solution:
The symptom complex in this patient coupled with a history of recent parotid surgery is indicative of Frey's syndrome, in which the auriculotemporal nerve marked as "D" is involved.

Frey’s syndrome/ Gustatory sweating (auriculotemporal syndrome):

It commonly develops after parotid surgery or other trauma that results in the opening of the parotid capsule. It results from damage to the autonomic innervation of the salivary gland. There is a regeneration of the parasympathetic nerve fibres that stimulate the sweat glands of the overlying skin in response to salivary stimulation or mastication. It is thought to reflect abnormal innervation of sweat glands on the face by regrowing parasympathetic secretomotor axons that would have previously innervated the parotid gland.

The clinical features include sweating, warmth, and erythema over the region of surgical excision of the parotid gland due to the autonomic stimulation of salivation by the smell/ taste of food.

Diagnosis is made using the starch iodine test. The affected area painted with iodine will turn blue on exposure to sweat.

It can be prevented by using a sternomastoid muscle flap, temporalis fascial flap, and insertion of an artificial membrane between the skin and the parotid bed. This will minimize the inappropriate regeneration of the autonomic nerve fibres. 

Treatment includes the use of antiperspirants with aluminium chloride, subcutaneous infiltration of purified botulinum toxin into the affected area and denervation by a tympanic neurectomy or auriculotemporal nerve avulsion. But is often not curative.

questions.text: Which of the following connects the structures marked as 'A' and 'B'?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as 'A' in the given image is lateral ventricle, and 'B' is third ventricle. The structure connecting these two is foramen of Monro.

The ventricular system is derived from the inner lumen of the developing neural tube. Lining the ventricles is the choroid plexus, consisting of modified ependymal cells responsible for producing the CSF. From the lateral ventricles, CSF flows through the interventricular foramen of Monro to the third ventricle. The third ventricle communicates with the fourth ventricle via the cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius (option A), which courses through the midbrain. Surrounded by the pons and medulla anteriorly and the cerebellum posteriorly, the fourth ventricle sends CSF out of the ventricular system and into the subarachnoid space via the lateral foramina of Luschka (option C) and midline foramen of Magendie (option D). 

Related Pearl: Boundaries of the 3rd ventricle

Roof: Choroid plexus

Lateral wall:

  • Thalamus
  • Hypothalamus

Anterior wall: 

  • Anterior commissure
  • Lamina terminalis

Posterior wall: 

  • Pineal gland
  • Posterior commissure
  • Aqueduct of Sylvius

Floor: 

  • Optic chiasma

questions.text:
What is the action of the muscle of mastication which is in close relation to the tonsillar bed?
  1. Depresses mandible
  2. Jaw protrusion
  3. Elevates mandible
  4. Jaw retraction
  5. Grinding movements
questions.solution:
The tonsilar bed is related to the medial pterygoid muscle which is a muscle of mastication. Its actions include elevation of the mandible, jaw protrusion and grinding(side to side) movements.

The tonsillar bed is formed by the superior constrictor and styloglossus muscles. Outside the superior constrictor, the tonsil is related to the facial artery, submandibular salivary gland, posterior belly of digastric muscle, medial pterygoid muscle and the angle of mandible

The medial pterygoid is a thick, quadrilateral muscle with two heads. The deep head arises from the medial surface of the lateral pterygoid plate of the sphenoid bone and the superficial head arises from the maxillary tuberosity and the pyramidal process of the palatine bone. It is inserted into the posteroinferior part of the medial surface of the ramus and the angle of the mandible.

It derives its main arterial supply from the pterygoid branches of the maxillary artery and it is innervated by the medial pterygoid branch of the mandibular nerve.

The medial pterygoids assist in elevating the mandible. Acting with the lateral pterygoids, they protrude it. When the medial and lateral pterygoids of one side act together, the corresponding side of the mandible is rotated both forward and to the opposite side. Alternating activity in the left and right sets of muscles produces side ­to ­side movements, which are used to grind food.

questions.text: Which among the following does not originate from the same cord of the brachial plexus as the nerve supplying the muscle involved in the following deformity?
questions.solution:
The deformity shown in the given image is due to a rupture of the tendon of biceps brachii is called the Popeye sign. It is supplied by the musculocutaneous nerve (C5,C6,C7) which is the terminal branch of the lateral cord. Superficial lateral cutaneous nerve of arm is from the posterior cord.

The lateral cord which is formed by the union of the anterior divisions of the upper and middle trunks lies anterior to the axillary artery. The medial cord which is formed by the union of the anterior division of the lower trunk lies medial to the axillary artery and the posterior cord which is formed by the fusion of the posterior divisions of all the trunks lies posterior to the axillary artery. 

Branches of lateral cord includes:

  1. Lateral pectoral nerve (C5-C7)- supplies both pectoralis major and pectoralis minor
  2. Musculocutaneous (C5-C7)- supplies muscles of anterior arm, coracobrachialis, biceps brachii and brachialis. 
  3. Lateral root of median (C5-C7) - joins the medial root of median nerve and supplies muscles of front of forearm and thenar muscles.

Related Pearl: Brachial Plexus

Brachial Plexus

  • C5 to T1
  • Roots (from spinal cord) > Trunks (in the neck)> Divisions (passing behind clavicle) > Cords and Branches (in the axilla).
  • Covered by prevertebral fascia extension called "axillary sheath"

Trunks:

  • Upper trunk: C5 and C6
  • Middle trunk: C7.
  • Lower trunk: C8 and T1

Divisions:

  • Anterior divisions - Forms lateral and medial cords supplying mainly flexors 
  • Posterior divisions - Forms posterior cord which suppy mainly extensors 

Cords:

  • Lateral cord: Formed by anterior divisions of the upper and middle trunks.
  • Posterior cord: Formed by all 3 posterior divisions 
  • Medial cord: Formed by anterior division of the lower trunk.

Branches:

questions.text: The structure marked as "A" in the image below is derived from -
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the Crystalline Lens. It is derived from the Surface Ectoderm.

The image below is the cross-section of the eye.

Embryological Development of the Eye

By approximately day 22, 2 small grooves appear on either side of the developing forebrain in the neural folds, these are called optic grooves. As the neural tube closes, these grooves develop outpouchings called optic vesicles. These optic vesicles extend from the forebrain to the surface ectoderm.

Some pathology that occurs in the lens during the developmental stages:

  • Developmental cataract: Punctate, Zonular, Fusiform, Nuclear, Coronary, Anterior Capsular (Polar), Posterior Capsular (Polar) cataracts
  • Coloboma of the lens (notch-shaped defect in the inferior margin)
  • Cataract associated with anterior persistent primary vitreous (PHPV)
  • Spherophakia, microphakia, microspherophakia (variations in the shape of the lens)
  • Lenticonus (abnormal curvature)
  • Ectopia lentis (congenital dislocation or subluxation of the lens)

Related Pearl: Embryological derivatives of the eye

questions.text: A histologist is studying the structure of lymphoid tissue. The histological features shown in the image below are seen in:
questions.solution:
The given slide shows the histology of tonsils with non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium and lymphoid nodules in the center.

The tonsil consists of lymphoid nodules, which are surrounded by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium on its oropharyngeal surface. The epithelium dips into the substance of the gland and forms tonsillar crypts.

The following image shows the histology of the tonsils:

 

Histology of thymus (option A):

The thymus is a lymphoid tissue that is arranged in the form of lobules. The lobules are separated from each other by connective tissue. 

Each lobule is made up of an outer darker staining cortex and an inner pale-staining medulla. The medulla contains pink rounded masses called Hassell's corpuscles.

 

Structure of a lymph node (option B):

Each lymph node is bean-shaped. The concave part consists of the hilum, through which the blood vessels enter and leave the node. Microscopy shows the following features:

Each lymph node is surrounded by a thin capsule. Below the capsule is the clear space, which is called the subcapsular sinus. 

The lymph node contains the outer cortex and an inner medulla. The cortex consists of densely packed lymphocytes and therefore stains dark. Numerous follicles can be seen in the cortex. Each nodule has a pale-staining germinal center surrounded by a zone of densely packed lymphocytes. The medulla consists of lymphocytes arranged in the form of anastomosing cords. It appears pale. Numerous blood vessels can be seen in this area.

The image below shows the histology of the lymph node:

 

Structure of spleen (Option D):

The spleen is the largest lymphoid organ of the body.

Microscopic features of the spleen:

It is surrounded by a thick capsule. This capsule extends into the organ forming trabeculae. The substance of the spleen consists of red pulp and white pulp. In red pulp, the lymphocytes are diffusely distributed and contain numerous sinusoids. In white pulp, the lymphocytes are densely packed and arranged in the form of cords around the arterioles.

When cut transversely, the cords are similar to the nodules in the lymph nodes. They have a pale germinal center surrounded by a ring of densely packed lymphocytes. However, there is an eccentrically placed arteriole within the germinal center.

The image below shows the spleen: WP- white pulp, RP- Red pulp, CR- central arteriole.

Structure of mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue:

The aggregations are in the form of lymphatic follicles. Germinal centers may be present. Between the nodules, there is diffuse lymphoid tissue, which is called a parafollicular zone. The nodules predominantly consist of B lymphocytes with T lymphocytes in the diffuse areas.

They lie close to the epithelium. They are not surrounded by a capsule and also do not have connective tissue septa. They have a supporting network of reticular fibers. Examples are palatine tonsils, Peyer's patches, and lymphoid nodules in the vermiform appendix.

The image below shows Peyer's patches.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding nutrient artery?

choices.text: The vessels terminate in the periosteum
It supplies outer 1/3rd of the cortex
The nutrient foramen is directed away from the growing end

questions.solution:
The nutrient foramen is directed away from the growing end is the only true statement regarding nutrient artery. 

A nutrient artery enters the shaft through the nutrient foramen. It then runs through the cortex, and divides into ascending and descending branches in the medullary cavity. Each branch then divides into numerous small branches. These branches run parallel to the main artery and end in metaphysis by anastomosing with the epiphysial, metaphysial, and periosteal arteries.

The nutrient artery supplies the medullary cavity, inner two-thirds of the cortex, and metaphysis.

Nutrient foramen is directed away from the growing end of the bone. It can be remembered as "to the elbow I go and from the knee, I flee".

Blood supply of the Bone
Artery Regions supplied
Nutrient artery  Medullary cavity, inner 2/3 of the cortex, metaphysis
Metaphyseal arteries Metaphysis
Epiphyseal arteries Epiphysis and growth plate
Periosteal arteries Periosteum, outer 1/3 of the cortex

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the structure marked in the given image?

choices.text: Formed by retromandibular vein and facial vein
Great auricular nerve runs with it
Pierces the deep cervical fascia in the carotid triangle

questions.solution:
The marked structure in the given image is the external jugular vein. It runs with the great auricular nerve, lying posterior to its upper half. 

The formative tributaries of the external jugular vein are the posterior auricular vein and the posterior division of the retromandibular vein (option A). It descends from the angle of the mandible to the midpoint of the clavicle, running obliquely and superficial to the sternocleidomastoid muscle. It is covered by skin, superficial fascia, and platysma, and is separated from the sternocleidomastoid by the deep cervical fascia. At the root of the neck in the posterior triangle (option D), it pierces the deep cervical fascia and ends in the subclavian vein (option C).  The vein crosses the transverse cutaneous nerve and lies parallel with the great auricular nerve, posterior to its upper half.

questions.text: What is the embryological precursor of the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is ligamentum teres and it is an embryological remnant of the left umblical vein.

questions.text: A young man is rushed to the emergency department after suffering a stab wound over the chest wall. The entry wound is present on the left side in the mid-axillary line. The lung is likely to be injured if the entry wound is above which level?
questions.solution:
The lung is likely to be injured if the entry wound is above the 8th rib. The lower border of the lung in the midaxillary line is at the level of the 8th rib. Hence, if the entry wound is above or at this level, the lung may be injured.

12th rib

10th rib

questions.text: You see a medicine resident examining pulses in the lower limb. He would palpate the dorsalis pedis artery by placing his fingertips between the tendons of:

choices.text: Extensor hallucis longus and extensor digitorum longus
Extensor hallucis longus and extensor digitorum brevis
Tibialis anterior and extensor digitorum longus
Extensor digitorum longus and extensor digitorum brevis

questions.solution:
The dorsalis pedis artery is palpated between the tendons of the extensor hallucis longus and extensor digitorum longus.

The pulsations of the dorsalis pedis artery are palpated just lateral to the extensor hallucis longus (EHL) tendon and are felt against the navicular and intermediate cuneiform bones.

The dorsalis pedis artery is the continuation of the anterior tibial artery on the dorsum of the foot. It begins between the two malleoli and runs on the medial side of the dorsum till the 1st intermetatarsal space and ends by completing the plantar arch. The structures related to this artery are:

Superficial relation - Skin, fascia, inferior extensor retinaculum, EHB which crosses from the lateral to the medial side.
Medial relation - Extensor hallucis longus
Lateral relation - First tendon of extensor digitorum longus
Deep relation - Capsular ligament of ankle joint. Talus, navicular, and intermediate cuneiform bones

Landmarks for palpation of other pulsations of the lower limb are:

Anterior tibial artery - anteriorly midway between the medial and lateral malleoli, lateral to the EHL tendon, against the lower end of the tibia

Posterior tibial artery - midway between the medial malleolus and the Achilles tendon, against the calcaneum.

Popliteal artery - with the knee flexed about 40-50°, at the lower part of the popliteal fossa, against the posterior surface of the upper end of the tibia.

Femoral artery - with the hip flexed to about 15°, just below the inguinal ligament, midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis, ie, at the mid-inguinal point.

questions.text: A study was conducted on guinea pigs to learn the effects of acetylcholinesterase antibodies in the spinal cord. Samples of antibodies were obtained from patients with myasthenia gravis and injected into the CSF of the guinea pig. Hours later, the guinea pigs showed signs of dysautonomia, which can be attributed to damage to which nucleus of the spinal cord?
questions.solution:
Features of dysautonomia suggest damage to the intermediate or intermediolateral nucleus of the spinal cord which is usually present in the lateral horns at the thoracolumbar level.

Dysautonomia refers to the malfunctioning of the autonomic nervous system. Acetylcholinesterase antibodies interfere with neuronal transmission in the nucleus which results in dysautonomia.

Nerve cell group Function
Substantia gelatinosa
  • Receives afferent fibres concerned with pain, temperature, and touch from the posterior root.
  • Furthermore, it receives input from descending fibres from supraspinal levels
Nucleus proprius
  • Receives fibres from the posterior white column that are associated with the senses of position and movement (proprioception),two-point discrimination, and vibration.
Nucleus dorsalis (Clarke’s column)
  • associated with proprioceptive endings (neuromuscular spindles and tendon spindles)
Visceral afferent nucleus
  • believed to be associated with receiving visceral afferent information.
Intermerdiolateral nucelus 
  • Sympathetic and parasympathetic outflow

questions.text: The muscle involved in the following activity also helps connect the pelvic girdle and vertebral column to the upper limb. Identify the nerve root supplying it.
questions.solution:
The thoracodorsal nerve (C6, C7, C8) is the nerve supply of latissimus dorsi, the muscle connecting the pelvic girdle and vertebral column to the upper limb, and is also involved in swimming shown in the image.

The latissimus dorsi is a large muscle of the lower back which connects the pelvic girdle to the upper limb. It originates from the posterior one-third of the outer lip of the iliac crest, posterior layer of the lumbar fascia, spines of T7-T12 vertebrae, lower four ribs and inferior angle of the scapula. It inserts onto the floor of the intertubercular sulcus in the humerus.

Its actions are adduction, extension and internal rotation of the arm. It is used in swimming, rowing, climbing, scratching the opposite scapula and folding the arm across the back. Therefore, it is also known as the “climbing muscle” or “swimmers muscle”. It also helps in forceful expiration and in holding the inferior angle of the scapula in place.

Long thoracic nerve or nerve to the serratus anterior arises from the roots of the brachial plexus, C5, C6, C7. It helps in overhead abduction along with trapezius.

Ulnar nerve originates from the medial cord of brachial plexus (C8, T1); However Ulnar Nerve near its origin, often receives a communicating branch from the lateral root of the median nerve originating from the lateral cord and carrying fibers from C7. Hence, it carries fibers from C7, C8, T1.

Phrenic nerve, originating from the cervical nerves C3, C4, C5, is a mixed nerve that carries motor fibres to the diaphragm and sensory fibres from the mediastinal pleura, pericardium, and a portion of the peritoneum.

questions.text: Which of the following areas is referred to as Sudeck's point?
questions.solution:
The rectosigmoid region is called Sudeck's point. This region receives its blood supply from the superior hemorrhoidal artery and distal sigmoid branches, both terminal branches of the IMA and prone to atherosclerotic changes.

Splenic flexure (also known as Griffith's point) is a watershed area between the superior and inferior mesenteric arteries.

questions.text: Which of the following veins drain into the structure related to the area marked 'A' in the diagram below?
questions.solution:
The diagram shown is of the right lung identified by the presence of hyparterial and eparterial bronchus at the hilum and the area marked A is where the azygos vein arches over the hilum of the right lung.

The right superior intercostal vein drains the 2nd, 3rd and 4th posterior intercostal veins on the right side of the body into the azygous vein.

Other options:

Option A: Left superior intercostal vein drains into the left brachiocephalic vein.

Option B: The first posterior (supreme) intercostal vein drains into the ipsilateral brachiocephalic or vertebral vein.

Option C: Left marginal vein courses near the left border of the heart, draining much of the left ventricular myocardium and drains into the great cardiac vein.

Related Pearl: Structures related to the mediastinal surface and hilum of the lungs

Right lung:

  • Anterior to the hilum - superior vena cava and right brachiocephalic vein.
  • Posterior to this groove-  azygous vein.
  • Behind the hilum and pulmonary ligament- oesophagus.
  • The cardiac impression - right auricle, right atrium and right ventricle
  • Posteroinferiorly - inferior vena cava

Left lung:

  • The cardiac impression - left ventricle and auricle and right ventricle
  • Large groove that arches over the hilum and descends behind -  Arch of aorta and descending aorta.
  • Arrow groove that ascends to the apex- left subclavian artery
  • Superior to the aortic groove-  thoracic duct and esophagus.
  • Anterior to subclavian groove - left brachiocephalic vein.

questions.text: As a resident, you are explaining the clinical anatomy to the medical students on your team. The structure marked "A" forms which of the following boundaries of the anatomic snuffbox?
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the image is the extensor pollicis longus and forms the medial/ulnar boundary of the anatomical snuff box. It passes medial to the Lister tubercle on the radius. 

Boundaries of the anatomical snuffbox: 

  • Lateral wall:
    • Abductor pollicis longus (APL)
    • Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)  
  • Medial wall:
    • Extensor pollicis longus (EPL)
  • Roof:
    • Cephalic vein
    • The superficial branch of the radial nerve
  • Floor:
    • Scaphoid and trapezium

Only content: Radial artery

The name "snuffbox" originates from the use of this surface for placing and then sniffing powdered tobacco, or "snuff."

questions.text: During dissection, the anatomy professor teaches about the spaces of the upper limb. He asks the students to look below a muscle, and observe a quadrangular space with the axillary nerve as one of its contents.  Which muscle is he talking about?
questions.solution:
The muscle he is talking about is the teres minor. It forms the superior boundary of the quadrangular space hence below it lies the quadrangular space with the axillary nerve passing through it. 

Quadrangular space (Foramen of Velpeau- QS)

Formed by:

  • Anteriorly: Subscapularis
  • Superiorly: Capsule of the shoulder joint, teres minor
  • Inferiorly: Teres major
  • Medially: Long head of triceps
  • Laterally: Surgical neck of humerus

Content:

  • Axillary nerve
  • Posterior circumflex humeral artery and vein

Boundaries and contents of other spaces around the shoulder joint:

Triangular space (TS) (Upper triangular space):

Boundaries:

  • Superiorly: Subscapularis anteriorly, teres minor posteriorly
  • Laterally: Long head of triceps
  • Inferiorly: Teres major

Contents: 

  •  Circumflex scapular artery

Triangular interval (TI) (Lower triangular space):

Boundaries:

  • Superiorly: Subscapularis anteriorly, teres major posteriorly
  • Medially: Long head of triceps
  • Laterally: Humerus

Contents:

  • Radial nerve
  • Profunda brachii vessels

Note: Radial nerve injury results in wrist drop.

An easy way to remember these spaces is to represent your 4 fingers as structures around the 3 spaces as shown below.

questions.text: Which of the following belongs to the same category of joints as the ones marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image given below shows the manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints which are secondary cartilaginous joints. Among the given options, the intervertebral joint belongs to the same category.

Secondary cartilaginous joints are characterized by the presence of a fibrocartilaginous disc that connects the articular surfaces, which are covered by a thin layer of hyaline cartilage. These joints are considered permanent.

Symphysis menti (Option A) is a misnomer as it is a synostosis and not a true symphysis. It has no cartilage between the two sides of the mandible. So, it is not the best answer among the given options.

Proximal and distal radioulnar joints are uniaxial pivot joints (synovial). They are involved in pronation and supination movements of the forearm (Option D).

Structurally, joints are classified as fibrous joints, cartilaginous joints, and synovial joints. 

 Type  Subtypes
Fibrous joints

Sutures
Syndesmosis
Gomphosis
Cartilaginous joints Primary cartilaginous (synchondrosis)
Secondary cartilaginous (symphysis)
Synovial joints Ball-and-socket or spheroidal joints
Sellar or saddle joints
Condylar or bicondylar joints
Ellipsoid joints
Hinge joints
Pivot or trochoid joints
Plane joints

Joints in the thoracic cavity are of the following types:

  • Synarthrosis - structures are connected by a fibrous band of tissue. Example: 1st sternocostal joint
  • Synchondrosis/primary cartilaginous joints. Example: costochondral joints (Option C)
  • Symphysis/secondary cartilaginous joints. Example: Manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints 
  • Synovial joints - the presence of these helps the thoracic cavity expand during inspiration. E.g.: Interchondral joint, Sternocostal joint, Costovertebral joint and Costotransverse joint.

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation (supination and pronation) Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text: A 40 year old man comes to the emergency room with hematemesis. On endoscopy, ulceration was found on the greater curvature of the stomach, approximately 3 cm away from the pyloric sphincter. Which artery is likely the cause of the bleed?
questions.solution:
For an ulceration on the greater curvature of the stomach, the artery likely involved in bleeding is the right gastroepiploic artery. It supplies blood to greater curvature of the stomach, and ulceration in this area can lead to bleeding from this artery.

Blood supply of the stomach:

The arterial supply of the stomach is contributed exclusively by the branches of the celiac trunk. They are:

  • Left gastric artery - supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach
  • Splenic artery - further divides into:
    - Short gastric arteries - supplies the fundus of the stomach
    - Left gastroepiploic artery - supplies the greater curvature of the stomach and anastomoses with the right gastroepiploic artery
  • Common hepatic artery, which gives the following branches:
    - Right gastric artery - supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach, anastomoses with the left gastric artery
    - Gastroduodenal artery - further divides into right gastroepiploic artery which supplies the greater curvature of the stomach and superior pancreaticoduodenal artery which supplies duodenum and head of pancreas and anastomoses with the inferior pancreaticoduodenal branch of the SMA

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was admitted with altered sensorium, hydrophobia, and seizures after he was bitten by a stray dog 4 weeks ago. The patient passed away and an autopsy was performed. Identify the layer of the cerebellar cortex in which the pathognomic intracellular inclusion bodies are usually seen.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is that of rabies encephalitis and the pathognomic intracellular inclusion bodies (Negri bodies) are seen in Purkinje cells belonging to the Purkinje cell layer (Layer C).

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers histologically. They are:

  • Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer that contains stellate cells and basket cells, and dendrites of Purkinje cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers. It appears pale on H and E staining.
  • Purkinje layer - contain the cell bodies of the Purkinje cells which are flask-shaped. Characteristics of Purkinje cells:
    • Flask-shaped, evenly spaced cells arranged in a single layer.
    • The only efferents of the cerebellar cortex.
    • A dendrite from the neck of each flask-shaped cell passes upward to the molecular layer and the axon passes down through the granular layer to the white matter.
    • Purkinje cells are inhibitory and use GABA as their neurotransmitter.
  • Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells. It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibers. They end the dendrites of the granule cells and these complexes are called glomeruli. The axon from the granule cells travels to the molecular layer and bifurcates in a T-shape. These branches from the T are called parallel fibers. These parallel fibers form excitatory synapses with the Purkinje cells. The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex. It also contains Golgi cells that receive input from parallel fibers and mossy fibers. They send inhibitory output to the granule cells.

Rabies presents initially with fever and paraesthesia near the bite, following which the patient becomes increasingly anxious, leading to hydrophobia, delusions, and hallucinations. On microscopic examination of the brain, there is neuronal degeneration with inflammation. Negri bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions seen in the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. (seen below)

Related Pearl: Layers of the cerebellar cortex

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers. They are:

  • Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer. It contains stellate cells and basket cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers giving it a pale appearance in H and E staining.
  • Purkinje layer - It is the middle layer. It contain flask-shaped cell bodies of Purkinje cells. Their dendrites pass into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells passes through the granular layer into the white matter and synapses with the cerebellar nuclei.
  • Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells as well as Golgi cells. It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibers. They end on the dendrites of the granule cells and these complexes are called glomeruli. The axon from the granule cells travels to the molecular layer and bifurcates in a T-shape. These branches form the T and are called parallel fibers. These parallel fibers form excitatory synapses with the Purkinje cells. The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex. Golgi cells receive input from parallel fibers and mossy fibers. They send inhibitory output to the granule cells.

Neurotransmitters released:

  • Stellate, basket, Golgi and Purkinje cells- GABA
  • Granule cells - Glutamate

The only output from the cerebellar cortex is inhibitory from the Purkinje cells to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text:
Match the following muscles with their type of oblique arrangement:
1. Extensor digitorum longus a. Bipennate
2. Flexor hallucis longus b. Unipennate
3. Tibialis anterior c. Cruciate
4. Adductor magnus d. Triangular
5. Adductor longus e. Circumpennate
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-b, 2-a, 3-e, 4-c, 5-d.

The following table shows the muscles and their respective oblique arrangements:

Extensor digitorum longus Unipennate
Flexor hallucis longus Bipennate
Tibialis anterior Circumpennate
Adductor magnus Cruciate
Adductor longus Triangular

 

Muscles with oblique fibers are subclassified as follows:

  • Triangular: They are triangular in shape. E.g., temporalis, adductor longus, trapezius.

  • Pennate: They are feather-shaped. Based on their complexity, they can have the following subtypes:
    • Unipennate: Fascicles on one side of the tendon. E.g., Flexor pollicis longus, extensor digitorum longus, palmar interossei
    • Bipennate: Fascicles on two sides of the tendon. E.g., flexor hallucis longus, dorsal interossei
    • Multipennate: Central tendon branches into two or more branches within the muscle. E.g., Deltoid, subscapularis
    • Circumpennate (radial): Muscle fibers converge to a central tendon in a radial fashion. E.g., Tibialis anterior

Related Pearl: Classification of muscles according to their shape/direction of muscle fibers

Muscles with parallel fasciculi

Muscles with oblique fasciculi

Muscles with spiral or twisted fasciculi

 

Quadrilateral: Thyrohyoid

Triangular: Temporalis, Adductor longus, 

Spiral: Pectoralis major, Latissimus dorsi, Supinator and Trapezius

Strap like: Sartorius, Sternohyoid

Unipennate: Extensor digitorum longus, Flexor pollicis longus, Peroneus tertius, Palmar interossei

Partially cruciate and partially spiral: Masseter, Adductor magnus, Sternoclediomastoid 

Strap like with tendinous intersections: Rectus abdominis

Bipennate: Rectus femoris, Flexor hallucis longus, Peroneus longus, Dorsal interossei

 

Fusiform: Biceps brachii, digastric

Multipennate: Deltoid, Subscapularis

  

 

Circumpennate: Tibialis anterior

questions.text: You are evaluating a cyanotic newborn with an echocardiogram showing pulmonic stenosis involving the root of the pulmonary artery. Which developmental structure's defective maturation is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
This newborn is found to have pulmonic stenosis involving the root of the pulmonary artery. The structure which gives rise to the root of the pulmonary artery is the truncus arteriosus which is marked as '4' in the given image.

questions.text: Where are the ossification centers resulting in bipartite patella most commonly located?
questions.solution:
The ossification centers resulting in a bipartite patella are most commonly located in the superolateral angle of the patella.

A bipartite patella (two-part patella) is a patella with an unfused accessory ossification center, typically at the superolateral aspect. It usually is asymptomatic and is noted incidentally, however pain, when present, can be caused by overuse (such as in a cyclist or climber).

There are three types of bipartite patella.

  • Type I (5%) occurs at the inferior pole.
  • Type II (20%) occurs along the entire lateral border of the patella.
  • Type III (75%) the most common type, occurs as an elliptical area in the superolateral portion of the patella.


Depending on the number of fragments they may be classified as bipartite, tripartite or multipartite.

For diagnosis, a conventional skyline view is followed by a skyline view with the patient in a squatting weight-bearing position to assess if pain is caused by a nonunion at the bipartite site. If the gap is higher in the squatting weight-bearing posture than in the standard skyline view, the test result is considered positive.

MRI is not required to diagnose the condition.

Treatment:

If pain occurs with a bipartite patella, limiting and restricting activity, correcting the activity that is causing an overuse syndrome, and prescribing nonsteroidal antiinflammatory agents can result in improvement in 3 weeks. 

Operative treatment with the Ogata technique is rarely necessary.

questions.text: During an anatomy lecture, your professor describes a lower limb nerve, related to the structure marked below. She also mentions that injury to this nerve causes loss of dorsiflexion and sensation over the lateral aspect of the leg and dorsum of the foot. Which of the following is not a branch of this nerve?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the structure marked in the given image is the neck of the fibula. The common fibular nerve (common peroneal nerve) passes around the lateral surface of the neck of the fibula and enters the lateral compartment of the leg.

The Lateral plantar nerve is not a branch of this nerve. It is a branch of the tibial nerve.

The common fibular is derived from the dorsal branches of the L4 - L5 and S1 - S2 ventral rami. It innervates the short head of the biceps femoris in the posterior compartment of the thigh and then continues into the lateral and anterior compartments of the leg and onto the foot.

It gives the following branches:

  • Sural communicating nerve (cutaneous branch)
  • Lateral sural cutaneous nerve (cutaneous branch)
  • Superficial fibular nerve 
  • Deep fibular nerve. 

Injury to the common peroneal nerve will lead to:

  • Weakness of dorsiflexion of foot or foot drop
  • Loss of dorsiflexion 
  • Loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the leg and dorsum of the foot.
  • Wasting of fibular and anterior tibial muscles.

The images given below show the common peroneal nerve course and the sensory area supplied.

questions.text: Match the gross structure with its histology.
questions.solution:
The given histological image is of transitional epithelium with a star-shaped appearance, which is a feature of the ureter. In the gross image provided, the structure labelled as 1 is the ureter, specifically the left ureter. 

The other structures marked are:

2: Inferior mesenteric artery

3: Descending colon 

4: Femoral cutaneous nerve 

Histology of ureter:

It has 3 layers- the innermost mucous membrane, the middle smooth muscle layer and the outer connective tissue layer.

The innermost mucous membrane is made of transitional epithelium. It is 4-5 cell layers thick with an underlying lamina propria. The mucosa is thrown into longitudinal folds which gives the lumen a star-shaped appearance. These folds vanish when the ureter is distended. 

The middle smooth muscle layer consists of an upper 2/3rd of inner longitudinal and outer circular fibres and a lower 1/3rd- of extra outer longitudinal muscle layer. The muscle coat has 2 layers in the upper 2/3rd and 3 layers in the lower 1/3rd, which may not be distinctly differentiated from each other. 

The outer connective tissue layer, also called the tunica adventitia contains blood vessels, nerves, lymphatics and fat cells. 

Ureters are narrow muscular tubes that begin from the renal pelvis and extend up to the urinary bladder. They are about 25cm long, and 3mm thick with 5 constrictions along their length. They are constricted at the pelvic-ureteric junction, the brim of the lesser pelvis, the crossing of the ureter by ductus deferens or broad ligament of the uterus, during their oblique passage through the bladder wall and at the opening in the lateral angle of the trigone.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient is posted for an inguinal hernia operation. The anesthetist intends to use a regional anesthesia technique that blocks the nerves in the anterior abdominal wall. Between which of the following structures would the anesthetist be injecting the drug mixture?

choices.text: Between internal oblique and external oblique
Between internal oblique and rectus abdominis
Between internal oblique and transversus abdominis

questions.solution:
The local anesthetic is injected between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles in the anterior abdominal wall. This is because the neurovascular plane of the abdominal wall lies between these two muscles.

The transversus abdominis plane (TAP) block is a regional anesthetic technique for abdominal surgery. 

The neurovascular plane of the abdominal wall lies between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis in the anterior abdominal wall.

The plane contains:

  • Lower 6 thoracic nerves (T7-12)
  • Iliohypogastric nerves
  • Posterior intercostal and subcostal vessels
  • Anastomosis between superior and inferior epigastric arteries

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient is diagnosed to have athetosis with tremors on one side and oculomotor nerve palsy on the opposite side. A diagnosis of Benedikt's syndrome is made. Damage to which of the following marked structure is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Benedikt's syndrome occurs due to injury to the red nucleus (Nucleus ruber) marked as 1 in the image. It is identified as it is located dorsomedial to the substantia nigra(Locus niger).

2- Thalamus

3- Internal capsule

4- Pons

Red Nucleus:

It is a rounded mass of grey matter located dorsomedial to the substantial nigra. It has a reddish hue in fresh specimens due to its extensive vascularity and the presence of ferric iron pigments in multipolar neurons.

The afferent connections of the red nucleus are from:

  • The cerebral cortex by the corticospinal fibres
  • The cerebellum through the superior cerebellar peduncle
  • The lentiform nucleus, hypothalamic and subthalamic nuclei, substantial nigra, and spinal cord.

Efferent connections of the red nucleus pass to 

  • The spinal cord by the rubrospinal tract
  • The reticular formation through the rubroreticular tract
  • The substantia nigra
  • The thalamus

Clinical correlate:

Injury to the red nucleus can cause Benedikt's syndrome characterized by ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy and contralateral tremors, chorea, and athetosis.

questions.text: While performing the axillary lymph node dissection, the following structure forming the superior boundary of dissection marked as ‘A’ is seen. Identify this structure.
questions.solution:
The space of axillary lymph node dissection is superiorly bounded by the axillary vein (marked as ‘A’).

Boundaries of axillary lymph node dissection(ALND) are as follows:

  • Superior- Axillary vein
  • Lateral- Thoracodorsal pedicle
  • Medial- Costoclavicular ligament (Halstead ligament)
  • Inferior- Angular vein    

Indications for ALND:

  1. Locally advanced (T4a, b, c) or inflammatory breast cancer.
  2. Metastatic disease in axillary lymph node(s) proven by needle biopsy, clinically palpable or nonpalpable but abnormal by imaging.

questions.text: An autopsy of a male patient who died in a road traffic accident was done. The structure marked as "A" was injured. Which of the following muscles is affected in the injury of this marked structure?
questions.solution:
The muscle affected in the injury of the marked structure "A" is sternohyoid.

The structure marked as A in the above image is the inferior root of ansa cervicalis.

Ansa cervicalis is a loop of nerves that are a part of the cervical plexus. It is made up of two roots. The superior root has contributions from the first cervical spinal nerve and the inferior root has contributions from the second and third cervical spinal nerves. The superior root (descendens hypoglossi) emerges out of the hypoglossal nerve and curves around the occipital artery. It descends anterior to the carotid sheath. 

The inferior root (descendens cervicalis) descends on the lateral side of the internal jugular vein and continues downwards to join the superior root anterior to the common carotid artery, forming the ansa cervicalis (ansa hypoglossi).

The two roots after joining innervate the sternohyoid, sternothyroid, and inferior belly of omohyoid muscles. The superior root before joining with the inferior root provides innervation to the superior belly of the omohyoid muscle.

Other options:

Options B and C- Thyrohyoid and geniohyoid are not supplied by ansa cervicalis. They are supplied by the first cervical spinal nerve, via the hypoglossal nerve.

Option D- Stylohyoid is supplied by the stylohyoid branch of the facial nerve.

questions.text: What is the anatomical equivalent of the marked structure in females?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as 'A' is the spermatic cord and its anatomical equivalent in females is round ligament.

The spermatic cord is a structure that passes through the inguinal canal in males. The inguinal canal is a natural passageway between the muscle layers of the anterior abdominal wall in the region of the groin. It transmits the spermatic cord in males, the round ligament of the uterus in females, and the ilioinguinal nerve in both sexes.

Coverings of the spermatic cord from inside to outside are:

  • Internal spermatic fascia is derived from fascia transversalis.
  • Cremasteric fascia is derived from the Internal oblique.
  • External spermatic fascia is derived from the external oblique aponeurosis.

The image below shows the contents of the spermatic cord:

questions.text: What is the primary drainage route of the deep facial vein?
questions.solution:
The primary drainage route of the deep facial vein is the facial vein, which then empties into the internal jugular vein.

Venous drainage of the face and scalp:

The blood from the face and scalp is mainly drained by the facial vein and retromandibular vein.

  • The supratrochlear and the supraorbital veins join at the medial angle of the eye to form the angular vein, which continues down as the facial vein.
  • The superficial temporal vein joins the maxillary vein to form the retromandibular vein. The retromandibular vein divides into anterior and posterior divisions.
  • The anterior division of the retromandibular vein joins the facial vein to form the common facial vein, which drains into the internal jugular vein.
  • The posterior division of the retromandibular vein joins with the posterior auricular vein to form the external jugular vein. The external jugular vein then drains into the subclavian vein.

The facial vein is valveless and connects with the cavernous sinus through the superior ophthalmic vein and with the pterygoid venous plexus through the inferior ophthalmic and deep facial veins. Hence any infection of the face may spread to the cavernous sinus and pterygoid venous plexus and lead to cavernous sinus thrombophlebitis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old college student sustained a knee injury during a basketball match in the sports fest. The orthopedic resident examines his knee which is positive for the sag sign. Identify the ligament affected.
questions.solution:
A positive sag sign is suggestive of injury to the posterior cruciate ligament, which is marked as '2' in the image shown.

1- Menisci

3- Anterior cruciate ligament

4- Fibular collateral ligament

The posterior cruciate ligament is attached to the lateral surface of the medial femoral condyle and extends up to the anterior part of the roof of the intercondylar fossa. Its fibres are adjacent to the articular surface. They have two bundles - Anterolateral and posteromedial bundles, which are named according to their femoral attachments.

There are two tests that can be used to diagnose anterior or posterior cruciate ligament laxity. 

Sag sign: Both the knees should be flexed to 90 degrees with the feet flat on the couch. In this position, inspect the upper part of the tibia from the side. If it has dropped back or can be gently pushed back, it is suggestive of a posterior cruciate ligament tear.

Drawer test: In the same position, anchor the foot by sitting on it. Grasp the upper end of the tibia with both hands and rock it backward and forwards to see if there is excessive movement in either direction. Excessive anterior movement is suggestive of anterior cruciate laxity while excessive posterior movement is suggestive of posterior cruciate laxity. 

The following image shows structures of the knee joint in the anterior view:

questions.text: What is the most common site of rib fracture?
questions.solution:
The most common site of rib fracture is the angle of the rib.

questions.text:
Arrange the following based on the vertebral levels of their diaphragmatic openings from superior to inferior.
  1. Azygous vein
  2. Left vagus nerve
  3. Right phrenic nerve 
  4. Thoracic duct
questions.solution:
Based on the vertebral levels of their diaphragmatic openings, the order of the structures from superior to inferior is:

3- Right phrenic nerve
2- Left vagus nerve
(1,4)- Azygous vein and thoracic duct (both pass through the same hiatus).

The diaphragm has several openings through which structures can pass between the thorax and abdomen. There are three large openings and several smaller openings. The large openings and structures passing through them are as follows:

HIATUS VERTEBRAL LEVEL CONTENTS
Caval  T8 Inferior vena cava and right phrenic nerve
Esophageal T10 Esophagus, right and left vagus nerve
Aortic T12 Aorta, thoracic duct, azygous, and hemiazygous vein.

 

Related Pearl: Diaphragmatic openings

Minor openings through the diaphragm

  • Space of Larry (Costo-Xiphoid gap) - Superior epigastric artery
  • Medial arcuate ligament - Sympathetic chain
  • Lateral arcuate ligament - Subcostal nerves and vessels

 

Note:

Splanchnic nerves pass through the right and left crus of the diaphragm.

The azygous vein may sometimes pass through the right crus of the diaphragm.

The hemizygous vein may sometimes pass through the left crus of the diaphragm.

questions.text: The plane passing through the center of the body, dividing it into two equal right and left halves, is known as __________
questions.solution:
The median plane is a longitudinal plane that divides the body into equal right and left halves. 

Four imaginary planes are used in anatomical descriptions:

  • Median (mid-sagittal) plane: Vertical plane that divides the body into equal right and left halves  
  • Sagittal plane: Vertical plane that divides the body into unequal right and left parts; parallel to the median plane
  • Coronal (frontal) plane: Vertical plane that divides the body into anterior and posterior parts; perpendicular to the median plane
  • Transverse (horizontal) plane: Horizontal plane that divides the body into upper and lower parts; perpendicular to both the sagittal and coronal planes

Note: Axial (or trans-axial) plane is a term used in radiology for the horizontal plane.

questions.text: A 35-year-male patient presents to the surgery outpatient unit with a history of blunt force trauma to the right side of the neck. He complains of an inability to comb his hair with his right hand. On examination, lateral winging of the scapula is noted on the right side. There is no difficulty in turning the head to the left side. The cause of his presentation is due to damage to the __________ nerve present in ____________ area of neck.
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes an injury to the spinal accessory nerve present in the occipital triangle which is a part of the posterior triangle of the neck.

The spinal accessory nerve has 2 roots: a cranial root that arises from the postolivary groove of the dorsolateral medulla and a spinal root that arises from the cervical segment of the spinal cord. The spinal root ascends the vertebral canal and passes through the foramen magnum to join the cranial root in the skull. The bundle of cranial and spinal roots divide into internal and external branches after leaving the jugular foramen. The external branch descends into the neck and while entering the occipital triangle, it pierces the sternocleidomastoid muscle supplying the muscle. It travels through the occipital triangle and reaches up to the trapezius and ends there. 

If the spinal accessory nerve is injured in the occipital triangle, the sternocleidomastoid will be spared but the trapezius will be affected resulting in :

  • Difficulty in overhead abduction
  • Difficulty in shrugging of shoulders
  • Lateral winging of the scapula
  • No difficulty in turning the head to the opposite side (due to sparing of sternocleidomastoid muscle)

 The posterior triangle of the neck is further subdivided into the occipital triangle and supraclavicular triangle.

Contents of the occipital triangle:

  • Occipital artery, branch of external carotid artery
  • Transverse cervical vessels
  • Spinal accessory nerve
  • Cutaneous and muscular branches of cervical plexus
  • Uppermost part of the brachial plexus
  • Supraclavicular nerve

Contents of the supraclavicular triangle:

  • Trunks of the brachial plexus
  • Nerve to subclavius
  • Supraclavicular nerves
  • Subclavian vessels 

Other options:

The long thoracic nerve arises from branches of the ventral primary rami of C5, C6 and C7. The trunk of the nerve passes posterolateral to the scalenus medius muscle, on the floor of the posterior triangle deep to the suprascapular nerve. It innervates the serratus anterior muscle. Due to its long course, the long thoracic nerve is susceptible to injury.

Winging of the scapula can be caused by paralysis of the serratus anterior or trapezius. It causes an inability to lift, pull and push heavy objects due to loss of power and limited flexion and abduction of the upper limb. Medial winging of scapula occurs in serratus anterior paralysis (long thoracic nerve injury) and lateral winging of scapula occurs in trapezius paralysis (spinal accessory nerve injury). 

The below image shows winging of the scapula due to trapezius paralysis.

The below image shows winging of scapula due to serratus anterior paralysis.

Related Pearl: Triangles of the Neck

questions.text: Which is the most inferior structure at the hilum of the left lung?
questions.solution:
The inferior pulmonary vein is the most inferior structure at the hilum of the left lung.

The usual vertical sequence of structures at the left hilum is (ABV)

  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal (hyparterial) bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

 

The usual vertical sequence of right hilar structures is BABV:

  • Superior lobar (eparterial) bronchus
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

Related Pearl: Structures related to the mediastinal surface and hilum of the lungs

Right lung:

  • Anterior to the hilum - superior vena cava and right brachiocephalic vein.
  • Posterior to this groove-  azygous vein.
  • Behind the hilum and pulmonary ligament- oesophagus.
  • The cardiac impression - right auricle, right atrium and right ventricle
  • Posteroinferiorly - inferior vena cava

Left lung:

  • The cardiac impression - left ventricle and auricle and right ventricle
  • Large groove that arches over the hilum and descends behind -  Arch of aorta and descending aorta.
  • Arrow groove that ascends to the apex- left subclavian artery
  • Superior to the aortic groove-  thoracic duct and esophagus.
  • Anterior to subclavian groove - left brachiocephalic vein.

questions.text: A patient presented with ophthalmoplegia. On radiological investigation, an aneurysm causing damage to the oculomotor nerve was noted. Which of the following arterial aneurysms is most likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
A posterior communicating artery aneurysm is most likely to cause damage to the oculomotor nerve, leading to ophthalmoplegia in this patient.

Circle of Willis is a large arterial anastomosis that unites the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems. It lies in the subarachnoid space within the basal cisterns that surround the optic chiasma and infundibulum.

Posterior communicating artery aneurysm: 

The posterior communicating artery (Pcom) links the middle and posterior cerebral arteries. It is located near the oculomotor nerve in the interpeduncular fossa. Therefore, an aneurysm of the Pcom will protrude and impinge upon the oculomotor nerve, leading to ophthalmoplegia.

Compression of the optic chiasma (central lesion) by an anterior communicating (Acom) artery aneurysm, will lead to bitemporal hemianopia i.e, loss of vision in the left/ temporal halves of both visual fields. Nasal fibers of each retina cross through the chiasma at this level and hence, these fibers will be compromised.

In the case of a bilateral peripheral lesion of the optic chiasma, bi-nasal hemianopia will be seen.

Other causes of chiasmal lesions are:

  • Pituitary adenoma (most common).
  • Craniopharyngioma.
  • Meningioma.
  • Glioma.

The blood supply of optic chiasma is via the left and right anterior cerebral arteries, along with the superior hypophyseal artery (branch of the internal carotid artery).

 The cadaveric image below is of the vascular structures (Circle of Willis) at the base of the brain.

Digital subtraction angiogram is the definitive imaging modality for aneurysms arising from the circle of Willis. Other investigations are CT and MRI.

Other options:

Aneurysms of the anterior communicating artery (option B), middle cerebral artery (option C) and anterior cerebral artery (option D) are anatomically not in close proximity to be able to compress the occulomotor nerve.

An anterior communicating artery (Acom) aneurysm is the most common intracranial aneurysm.

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text:
You are assisting your senior in fetal cardiac surgery. He asks you to identify vessels A and B.

View of the heart from below upwards.

choices.text: A- Pulmonary vein, B- Pulmonary artery
A- Pulmonary artery, B- Pulmonary vein

questions.solution:
The vessel 'A' is aorta and 'B' is pulmonary artery in the given image. The aorta lies anterior and right to the pulmonary artery. Posterior and right to aortic opening lies the opening of superior vena cava.

The image below shows the posterior view of the heart demonstrating openings of major vessels in heart.

questions.text: In the context of surgical planning for a thigh flap procedure, which branch of the lateral circumflex femoral artery is most critical for ensuring blood supply to the anterolateral thigh fasciocutaneous flap?

choices.text: Main trunk of the lateral circumflex femoral artery

questions.solution:
The descending branch of the lateral circumflex femoral artery is most critical for ensuring blood supply to the anterolateral thigh fasciocutaneous flap.

The lateral circumflex femoral artery is a key artery in the thigh that branches off from the profunda femoris artery. It travels sideways across the thigh and splits into three main branches:

  • Ascending branch - connects with superior gluteal and deep circumflex iliac arteries to supply blood to the greater trochanter and forms a ring of blood supply around the femoral neck. It helps in forming tensor fasciae latae musculocutaneous flap.
  • Descending branch - provides blood to the vastus lateralis and connects with the superior lateral genicular branch of the popliteal artery. It helps in forming anterolateral thigh fasciocutaneous flap.
  • Transverse branch - smallest branch that connects with medial circumflex, inferior gluteal, and first perforating arteries to form cruciate anastomosis around the thigh.

questions.text: The image below shows the anterior surface of the left kidney. Which of the following areas is related to jejunum?
questions.solution:
The area on the anterior surface of the left kidney related to the jejunum is 2.

The other structures marked in the image are: 1 - pancreas, 3 - left colic flexure, and 4 - descending colon. 

The anterior relations of the left kidney include:

  • Left suprarenal gland 
  • Stomach
  • Pancreas
  • Jejunum
  • Spleen
  • Splenic flexure and the beginning of the descending colon

 The anterior relations of the right kidney include:

  • Right suprarenal gland
  • Second/ descending part of the duodenum
  • Liver
  • Hepatic flexure of the colon
  • Small intestine

The posterior relations of the kidneys are as follows:

  • Vessels - subcostal vessels
  • Ligaments - medial and lateral arcuate ligaments
  • Nerves - subcostal, iliohypogastric, and ilioinguinal nerves
  • Muscles - diaphragm, psoas major, quadratus lumborum, and transversus abdominis
  • Ribs -
    • Right kidney is related to the 12th rib 
    • Left kidney is related to the 11th and 12th rib

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding the marked structure in the given image.

choices.text: Originates from the the tendon of flexor digitorum profundus

questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given image is the first lumbrical and it arises from the tendon of flexor digitorum profundus.

There are four lumbrical muscles. They originate from the tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus (option B). They then pass to the radial side of the corresponding fingers and are inserted into the dorsal digital expansion of the extensor digitorum. While the first and second lumbricals are unipennate in nature(Option D), the third and the fourth are bipennate.

The median nerve innervates the first and second lumbricals. The deep terminal branch of the ulnar nerve innervates the third and the fourth (option C). The action of lumbricals is flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joint and extension of interphalangeal joints (option A).

questions.text: The image below shows the dissection of the right side of the neck, and the red arrow denotes the right subclavian artery. What is not true about the structure labeled as A?

choices.text: It arises mainly from C4 spinal nerve.
The right side nerve is shorter than the left.
It is formed at the lateral border of scalenus anterior.
It is purely a motor nerve.

questions.solution:
The structure labeled as A is the right phrenic nerve, and it is a mixed nerve (sensory and motor nerve).

 It is derived mostly from the C4 ramus and also receives contributions from the C3 and C5 ventral rami. It is formed at the lateral border of scalenus anterior.

At the root of the neck, the right phrenic nerve runs anterior to the second part of the right subclavian artery from which it is seperated by scalenus anterior muscle. The phrenic nerve lies posterior to the right subclavian vein.

Right phrenic nerve is shorter and more vertical than the left.

Each phrenic nerve provides the sole motor supply to its hemidiaphragm. In its thoracic course, each phrenic nerve supplies sensory branches to the central parts of the diaphragm.

questions.text: Choose the correct sequence of structures on the ala of sacrum from lateral to medial side.

choices.text: Obturator nerve, iliolumbar artery, lumbar plexus, sympathetic plexus
Sympathetic plexus, lumbar plexus, iliolumbar artery, obturator nerve
Lumbar plexus, iliolumbar artery, obturator nerve, sympathetic plexus
Iliolumbar artery, obturator nerve, sympathetic plexus, lumbar plexus

questions.solution: Structures on the ala of sacrum from lateral to medial side are obturator nerve, iliolumbar artery, lumbar plexus,and sympathetic plexus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true with reference to the development of the brain?

choices.text: The superior cerebellar peduncles develops from the metencephalon
The rhombomeres 2 and 3 contains the motor nucleus of the facial nerve
The cervical flexure is present between the metencephalic part of the rhombencephalon and the spinal cord
The pontine flexure is directed ventrally between the metencephalon and myelencephalon

questions.solution:
During the development of the brain, the pontine flexure is present between the metencephalon and myelencephalon parts, of the rhombencephalon, and is directed ventrally.

The developing brain consists of three major divisions: prosencephalon (forebrain), mesencephalon (midbrain), and rhombencephalon (hindbrain).

  • The prosencephalon gives rise to the telencephalon, diencephalon 1 (D1) and diencephalon 2 (D2), which has three subdivisions.
  • The mesencephalon is subdivided into mesencephalon 1 (M1) and mesencephalon 2 (M2).
  • The rhombencephalon is subdivided into the isthmusrhombencephali and rhombomeres 1–8.

The following table shows derivatives of the cerebral regions from caudal to rostral

Medulla oblongata

Caudal part of the fourth ventricle

2.     Metencephalon

Note: Newer studies oppose the older model of brain development and suggest that instead of 3 anatomical divisions, it is better to divide it into anterior and posterior divisions. 

The pattern of the distribution of the motor nuclei associated with the rhombomeres is as follows:

Division of the rhombomeres Associated motor nuclei
Rhombomere 1 Trochlear nucleus
Rhombomeres 2 and 3 Trigeminal nucleus
Rhombomeres 4 and 5 Facial nucleus
Rhombomere 5 Abducens nucleus
Rhombomeres 6 and 7 Glossopharyngeal nucleus
Rhombomeres 7 and 8 Vagal, accessory, and hypoglossal nuclei

Flexures of the developing brain:

The prosencephalon, mesencephalon, and rhombencephalon are initially arranged craniocaudally, which is altered by the formation of various flexures as below:

  • Cervical flexure: Present between the myelencephalic part of the rhombencephalon and the spinal cord.
  • Cephalic flexure: Also known as mesencephalic flexure. It is present in the region of midbrain and is concave ventrally.
  • Pontine flexure: It is present between the metencephalon and myelencephalon
  • Telencephalic flexure: It occurs between the telencephalon and the diencephalon.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the direct branches of the external carotid artery?
  1. Inferior thyroid artery
  2. Lingual artery
  3. Occipital artery
  4. Pre-auricular artery
  5. Maxillary artery
  6. Deep temporal artery
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the branches of the external carotid artery (ECA) are the lingual artery, occipital artery, and maxillary artery.

The 8 branches of the external carotid artery are as follows:

  • Anterior branches:
    • Superior thyroid artery
    • Lingual artery
    • Facial artery
  • Posterior branches:
    • Occipital artery
    • Posterior auricular artery
  • Medial branch:
    • Ascending pharyngeal artery
  • Terminal branches:
    • Maxillary artery
    • Superficial temporal artery

The following dissected image shows the branches of ECA:

The following image shows the branches of common carotid artery:

Other options:

Inferior thyroid artery: It is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk, which, in turn, arises from the front of the first part of the subclavian artery.

Deep temporal artery: It is a branch of the maxillary artery, which is, in turn, a branch of the external carotid artery(ECA). It is to be noted that the deep temporal artery is not a direct branch of the ECA.

Related Pearl: Internal carotid artery branches

Part
Course
 Branches
Cervical part
Originates from the bifurcation of the common carotid artery. It has a dilation at the lower end which is known as carotid sinus. It ascends in front of the transverse process of the upper three cervical vertebrae.
 No branches given
Petrous part
Passes through the carotid canal in the petrous part of the temporal bone
  • Caroticotympanic branch
  • Artery to the pterygoid canal
Cavernous part
Runs in the cavernous sinus
  • Branch to the trigeminal ganglion
  • Meningeal branch
  • Branch to the cavernous sinus
  • Hypophyseal branches
Cerebral part/ Supracavernal part
Enters subarachnoid space by piercing arachnoid mater and divides into the anterior and middle cerebral arteries.
  • Ophthalmic artery
  • Anterior choroidal artery
  • Posterior communicating artery

The petrous, cavernous and intracranial parts of the internal carotid artery are called the carotid siphon because of its sigmoid course.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is supplied by the structure marked as 'X' in the following image?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as 'X' is the recurrent laryngeal nerve. It supplies posterior cricoarytenoid muscle which is an intrinsic muscle of the larynx. All the intrinsic muscles of the larynx are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve except for cricothyroid, which is supplied by the external laryngeal nerve.

The cervical part of sympathetic trunk lies anterior to longus colli and longus capitis muscles (enclosed in prevertebral fascia) and posterior to the common carotid artery. Sympathetic trunk lies outside the carotid sheath.

Other options:

Option A: Stylopharyngeus is supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX).

Option C: Cricothyroid is supplied by the external laryngeal nerve.

Option D: Diaphragm is supplied by the phrenic nerve.
